fields.standfirst: Nasa launches its Iris spacecraft from California on Thursday on a mission to discover how the sun creates its outer atmosphere or corona and the solar wind. The 7ft-long spacecraft is mounted on the nose of the winged Pegasus rocket and will be released to complete the journey. Iris will point a telescope at the region between the sun and the corona to see how energy moves from one to the other and generates the 'space weather' that affects the Earth

webTitle: Gavrilo Princip is arrested after assassinating Archduke Ferdinand

fields.standfirst: On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Sophie were assassinated in Sarajevo by a Yugoslav nationalist, Gavrilo Princip.  Bosnia and Herzegovina had been annexed by Austria-Hungary in 1908 and the archduke was there in his role as Inspector General of the Armed Forces of Austria-Hungary.  The Serbian government were blamed for the assassination and, on 28 July 1914, war was declared on Serbia by Austria-Hungary, who had the support of Germany.  Russia backed Serbia and the peace between Europe's great powers had begun to disintegrate
fields.headline: Gavrilo Princip is arrested after assassinating Archduke Ferdinand
fields.trailText: On 28 June 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Sophie were assassinated by a Yugoslav nationalist, Gavrilo Princip, in Sarajevo

fields.headline: In translation: nine authors pick their favourite children's fiction

tags.bio: David Almond is a novelist, and professor of creative writing at Bath Spa University. He lives in Northumberland. He has won the Whitbread Children's Book Award twice, for Skellig and The Fire-Eaters. Skellig was also awarded the Carnegie Medal.

Sally Gardner is an award-winning novelist from London. Her books have been translated into 22 languages and she's sold over 1.5 million copies in the UK. She was awarded the 2013 Carnegie medal for her book Maggot Moon

Adele Geras was born in 1944 and since 1976 has written more than 90 books for children of all ages. She has also published three novels for adults (Facing the Light, Hester's Story, and Made in Heaven, all published by Orion) and reviews children's books for the Guardian. She lives in Manchester and has two children and two grandchildren
Meg Rosoff was born in Boston and lives in London. She is the author of How I Live Now and Just In Case. She blogs here.

webTitle: Clashes in Alexandria after peaceful protests by Egyptians turn sour - video

fields.standfirst: Police and anti-government protesters, who want the removal of Mohamed Morsi, clash in several cities despite a day of seemingly-peaceful protest in Cairo. Two people - one US citizen - were reported killed in Alexandria amid running battles between police and public
